entries.text: Miyagawa presents here his latest offering: a tool that  creates a shell script and cpanm bundle to install modules on a remote machine  without cpanm installed and no network connection.
entries.title: cpan-module-bootstrap

entries.author: jt_smith
entries.text: JT Smith announces: a new release of the Perl wrapper for Firebase, the real-time web database, is out.
entries.title: Firebase 0.0201

entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.text: It is only poetic justice that the creator of Dist::Zilla got to go to Tokyo for YAPC::Asia . Ricardo Signes narrates for us here his YAPC::Asia 2013 experience.
entries.title: I went to Tokyo!

entries.text: Lestrrat offers us a recap of the awesome YAPC:Asia 2013, which saw  an impressive 1,131 attendees.
entries.title: A Lookback of YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2013

entries.text: Oylenshpeegul offers us a pretty comprehensive overview of all the different ways roles are implemented in Perl. So, I guess that we can say that, in a  way, he's basically rickroling us (hey, *he* started with the puns). ## Discussion
entries.title: That's how we role!

entries.text: Martin J. Evans had his first experience with Travis. He thinks he liked it.
entries.title: My first experience of travis-ci with DBD::ODBC and repercussions

entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.text: Lexical subroutines is a new feature introduced in Perl 5.18.0. Ricardo Signes tells us what they are, and what use they have.
entries.title: Lexical subroutines in perl 5

entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.text: Moose by itself is already scrumptious, but most of us top it with  MooseX:: extras to make it even better. In this article, Ovid shows how  to shave on the boilerplate that the import of all those extra modules require.
entries.title: Building your own Moose

entries.text: Hashes. They are darn versatile. Here, Vincent Veselosky proves the point and shows us a few tricks to  juggle with them most effectively.
entries.title: Hash slices can replace loops

entries.author: reini_urban
entries.text: Reini Urban shares with us his graphical, Win32-native Sudoku solver.
entries.title: Games

entries.author: reini_urban
entries.text: Schokidoki (aka. Alex) has resurrected Petris, a Tetris clone written in Perl/Tk. He even made a YouTube video and inspired Reini Urban to post his game.
entries.title: Games in Perl/Tk

entries.text: The New York Perl mongers are using Google Hangout to livestream their talks.  Want to emulate them? Samuel Kaufman gathers here all the steps and tricks
entries.title: HOWTO: Youtube live streaming of a talk

entries.author: olaf_alders
entries.text: The Toronto.pm Perl Monger meetings are also boldly shattering geographical limitations. Olaf Alders announces how the group is now broadcasting live via Google Hangout, and urges us to join the fun.
entries.title: Toronto.pm monthly meetings are now streamed live

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
chapters.title: Events

header: More and more Perl Monger meetings are bursting out of their geographical niches by offering a live stream of their talks. Thanks to this new movement, one can now attend to the Perl Monger meetings in San Francisco, New York and Toronto without the hassle of renting a private plane. Nifty, eh?  - `/anick
subject: Perl Monger Meetings Are Going Full Streaming Ahead
